text: [Music]
there's really no point trying to

I'm gonna try my best to give a really
quick summary here we go a plane crashes
on a mysterious island
the survivors each with their own dark

survive and hopefully escape but the
island has unique magnetic properties
that allow it to avoid detection from

through space in time making it almost
impossible for the survivors to leave
the source of all this power comes from
a light at the centre of the island this
light represents the goodness of all
mankind Jacob is the protector of the
island but his brother the man in black
wants to extinguish the light so he can
escape the island
so basically Jacob is good incarnate and
the man in black is evil incarnate if
the light were to go out the man in

throughout the world Jacob has already

the brothers are incapable of harming

as Jacob searches for his replacement

the others nuclear bombs polar bears the

you see pointless the two-part premiere
aired on September 22nd and 29th of 2004
at the time it was the most expensive

it was also the most watched pilot at

and after all these years I still think
that lost has the best pilot episode
I've ever seen it has all the elements
in effect
should have a unique premise a
fully-realized world profound themes
clearly defined conflicts a diverse cast
of flawed characters a mysterious hook
at the beginning and end and a simple

allows all these elements to be explored
in an effective way
lost wrecked up a number of prestigious
awards throughout at 60s and run it had
a profound and lasting effect on the
countless viewers who fervently watched
it combing and dissecting every detail
from week to week to the show finally
concluded on May 23rd 2010 but for a

cultural legacy lost left behind is a
mixed one marred and negativity and
cynicism in this video I want to explore
the history and lasting legacy of lost
pinpointing low moments throughout the
show's sixth season run as I search for
the day lost died not only do I think
that lost has one of the best pilots of
all time but I think the first season as
a whole might be my favorite single
season of a TV show
there wasn't a bad episode in the entire
season that was full of twists and turns
as we learned more about the characters
through use of flashbacks despite a
lackluster episode or two season two was
fantastic as well it was really only
during season 3 that mediocre episodes
began to pile up more frequently
flashbacks were once an effective and
engaging storytelling device but by
season three they became repetitive and
hindered forward momentum of the
storyline and this issue became
painfully obvious in what might be the
worst episode of the entire series
stranger in a strange land from the very
first episode flashbacks were used to
enrich the storm they told us who these
people were before they got to the
island hinted at how they all might be
connected and gave insight into their
motivations on the island but by season
3 most characters had fully fleshed out
their backstory and had nothing else to
tell now instead of enriching the
characters the flashbacks only seemed to
enrich the larger mythology they were
only interesting as a way to plant small
clues and insights but didn't really
matter anymore when it came to defining
the characters whereas Jack's flashbacks
in season 1 tell the audience about his
marriage to Sara and his troubled
relationships with his father
stranger in a strange land tells the
audience about the origins of his tattoo
it was a pointless storyline that made
for such a dull episode Kosho runner
Carlton Cuse admitted in an interview
that by season 3 the writers didn't know
what else to explore with checks passed
the first half of season 3 felt like the
show was spinning its wheels and it was
the general thinking of TV studios at
the time was if a show is still making
money and keep it going for as long as
possible that way of thinking worked for
hundreds of shows in the past but lost
was a unique show built upon a central
mystery and a definitive end point but
since lost was so successful for ABC the
studio tried to stretch it out for as
long as possible which meant that the
writers found themselves having to spend
their wheels indefinitely and they did
this with flashbacks with no endpoint in
sight flashbacks became longer and less
essential this issue became so apparent
in the episode stranger in a strange
land that showrunners Lindelof and Cuse
approached the network and pointed to
this specific episode as evidence to the
detriment that spinning wheels
indefinitely would have for the show
ABC relented and agreed to give the
writers three truncated seasons to tell
the story they wanted to tell because of
that loss was able to regain its
creative focus and move forward to a
definitive ending the slower pace of
season 3 was then replaced with a more
streamlined narrative through seasons 4
& 5 pointless flashbacks were replaced
with flash-forwards in season 4 and
jumps in time in season 5 and in season
6 we were given flash sideways
storylines leading to the conclusion in
the final episode at the end the series
finale that split the entire fan base in
half there were those who really enjoyed
the way Lindelof cues and the writers
resolved the storylines and mythology
and others who were severely
disappointed that six years of rabbit
dissection and devotion had led to a
small Church in purgatory a large issue
with season six as a whole is that the
flash sideways scenes meant absolutely
nothing to the overall plot on the
island it had nothing to do with Juliet
smacking the bomb at the end of season
five
it had nothing to do with saving the
island or defeating the man in black
that made for a slower paced more
disconnected final season and it even
felt like a cheat
since Lindelof and Cuse repeatedly said
from the beginning that lost wasn't
about purgatory the speculation they
were debunking was that the island was a
purgatory and to their credit it wasn't
but watching a plotline throughout
season six that revolved entirely in
purgatory still felt like a slight trail
and by the time the series came to an
end we were left with a pile of
unanswered questions and abandoned plot
lines it felt like the writers just gave
up knowing that it would be impossible
to tie up all the loose ends they
created over six years and they were
probably right and so in the final
episode the end the writers refocused on
what was most important the characters
and its core lost was a show about
broken flawed people finding redemption
through community that's the theme lost
always hit on throughout the series we
can't live together we're gonna die
alone they all needed each other in
order to find hope and meaning in their
lives and the writers made sure to
reinforce this theme in the series
finality the ending definitely felt
cheesy but I didn't mind that as much as
the fact that the end felt rushed and
haphazard in its execution to the
writers credit they told the story they
wanted to tell or at least the best
version of the story they could while
juggling writer strikes and sudden cast
departures over the run of the series
audience expectations were impossibly
high but again that's what happens when
a show continually kicks the can of
answers down the road week after week
after week
despite continuously dangling a carrot
in front of the audience with marketing
that always says this week all your
questions will be answered but I don't
think the end is the day Lost died I
think it died two episodes prior on May
11 2010 in the episode across the sea an
episode where the audience was finally
given answers but didn't like the
answers they were given or the way in
which they were presented a major
frustration throughout the run of Lost
was that the creator's struggled to
strike the right balance
between mythology and character at
different times they would seem to
flip-flop back and forth about their
importance did it all matter or did none
of it matter like any show the
characters should be the most important
aspect because if the audience doesn't
care about them then there is nothing at
stake there's no drama but lost was
unique because I'd argue that the
mythology was equally important to the
success and longevity of the show the
show wasn't a success purely for the
characters or the mythology it was the
two working in tandem watching our
characters as they interacted and
struggled with the mythology and
mysteries is what made the show work and
the island wasn't just an engaging
playground to watch the characters
struggle and grow the island itself with
all its mythology history and conflict
was a complex character in its own right
and all of those aspects were examined
in the episode across the sea the
episode is purely expositional vomiting
six seasons worth of answers into the
shape of an allegorical story of good
versus evil and while I appreciated some
actual answers an insight into the
backstory of the island I didn't like
how the third to last episode was
completely a flashback not only did it
take us away from the main characters
but it felt like the Ford momentum that
was building to the final episode hit a
brick wall and stopped dead the writers
waited in to the last minute to finally
give us answers and so they couldn't do
it in a nuanced way they had to cram in
as much as they could at the last minute
I think the writers hoped that by simply
asking big questions the story would
seem more sophisticated and deep but it
really just came across as Hollow and
I think a large portion of the fanbase
genuinely enjoyed the way lost ended and
I think another portion forced
themselves to enjoy the ending despite
its faults because what was the
alternative they spent six years
invested in the show that couldn't be
all for nothing and then there's another

out hated the ending of lost for those
people who were invested in the
mythology and the mysteries of lost
here's what showrunner Damon Lindelof

we had to say you were warned it's not

after you've wielded the promise of

that's not fair as I've said before the
characters in the mythology are tied
together
you can't minimize one without damaging

and that was the delicate balance that
worked so well until the writers
stumbled to the finish line independent
of whether or not you hated or loved the

people are still talking about it and
have very strong feelings about it
that's the intention of any art to
basically last if it lasts you're saying
something even if people are saying it's
something they don't necessarily like
with lost there's a fixation over the
way that it ended and I think that in
and of itself that's a very interesting
legacy for the show to have the legacy
of lost is a mixed bag immediately
following the show's finale there were
multiple copycat shows that came out the
following years seeking to fill the
high-concept void left in Lost's absence
but shows like flash-forward the event
persons unknown and alcatraz didn't last
long
as audiences were hesitant to invest in
another show built around a single
mystery loss took a lot of missteps
throughout its run but to its credit
that's because loss was taking creative
Gamble's that previous shows hadn't
high-concept ultra serialized nonlinear
structure with a large ensemble
and a definitive end point this went
against traditional logic of television
but that's exactly what made lost unique
and people responded to them and now
that's the norm in the landscape of
television no longer a show is reduced
to the lowest common denominator studios
have finally realized that audiences are
more sophisticated and open to complex
engaging storytelling when I think back
on lost I try my best to disconnect the
first five and a half seasons from the
final few episodes because I really
don't want it's mediocre ending to ruin
what was such a fun ride leading up to
that point
hours and hours spent obsessively
researching online and debating theories
with my friends and family but it's hard
reconciling the fact that the writers
didn't have some grand scheme in mind
sure they had a general idea of the
beginning and end but the clues planted
in every episode were just bread crumbs
to keep me watching I trusted that the
writers were in full control and knew
what they were doing every step of the
way but they continued avoiding answers
with more questions and more questions
until I was finally given some semblance
of an answer that I didn't want I want
to summarize this inner conflict with
lost into some profound closing thought
but I keep coming back to this blog post
by Jason plank that I think does it
better it perfectly encapsulates the way
that I and many other lost fans feel
about the ending of the show so I'll
leave you with this what made the show
great and ultimately an intellectual
success where the theories created by
the viewers the level of dialogue we
experienced the questions that were
debated until the Sun rose that is where
lost succeeded by showing us that we
were just as lost as the creators
themselves that our individual
experience is the only thing of
importance that what we take away from
it defines who we actually are maybe the
island wasn't the heart of the show
maybe the survivors weren't the blood
that was pumped
- our oxygen-starved cells maybe the
rabid fan base was the heart and our
experience observing the island was
where we found our little slice of
redemption that will be lost legacy a
convoluted story inside a manufactured
box of mystery a frivolous bow placed on
top which posed as something deeper than
what we initially believed a failure of
a measurable magnitude from a
storytelling standpoint a failure in the
end game and yet an ultimate success one
that taught us we were the survivors on
the island that our thirst for a final
answer wasn't what made the show special
it was our experiences that did a lot of
